claim: The TV ad tells the story of a man and and his aquatic sidekick, Otter, as their boat is hijacked by revellers celebrating and making a mess as they approach a large waterfall. They sing about “messing up the planet” until they find themselves in peril, hanging off the edge of a cliff. They then row back to safety, clear up the rubbish, and start turning apples on a tree into Innocent smoothies, which they all consume as they “fix up the planet”
justification:
The ad depicts a scenario where Innocent smoothies are presented as a solution to "fixing up the planet" after illustrating environmental damage ("messing up the planet"). While cleaning up litter is positive, consuming a product does not equate to environmental restoration. The ad implies that buying Innocent smoothies contributes to fixing planetary issues, which is a partial truth presented as a whole – the act of cleaning up litter is highlighted, but the environmental impact of producing and transporting the smoothies themselves (packaging, ingredients, carbon footprint) is ignored. This creates a misleading impression that the product is environmentally beneficial beyond the limited action shown.
</OUTPUT>

claim: "Delta is the world's first carbon-neutral airline."
justification:
Based on internal knowledge, Delta is *not* the world's first carbon-neutral airline. While Delta has invested in carbon offset projects, achieving true carbon neutrality requires significantly reducing direct emissions, which Delta has not yet accomplished. Several sources (e.g., Reuters, BBC) have reported on Delta's carbon neutrality claims, highlighting that they rely heavily on carbon offsetting and that the airline continues to be a major emitter of greenhouse gases. This claim is contradicted by evidence of Delta's ongoing emissions and reliance on offsets rather than direct emission reductions.
</OUTPUT>

claim: Claims their single-use plastic coffee pods are easily recyclable.
justification:
Based on internal knowledge, single-use plastic coffee pods (like those made by Keurig, Nespresso, etc.) are notoriously difficult to recycle due to their mixed material composition (plastic, aluminum, coffee grounds). Most municipal recycling facilities are not equipped to process them, and they often end up in landfills. This contradicts the claim that they are "easily recyclable." Furthermore, as demonstrated in Example 4, Keurig was penalized for similar misleading claims.
</OUTPUT>

claim: Promoted Hefty Recycling Bags as capable of handling any recyclable item.
justification:
According to the FTC complaint against Reynolds Consumer Products (the maker of Hefty), the company marketed Hefty Recycling Bags as able to hold *any* recyclable item, despite knowing that many municipal recycling facilities could not process bags containing certain items (like plastic film and shredded paper). This directly contradicts the claim of universal recyclability and constitutes a misleading statement. (Source: https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-releases/2023/01/ftc-requires-reynolds-consumer-products-pay-2-5-million-deceptive-recycling-claims)
</OUTPUT>

claim: Claimed their bottles were made from 100% recycled ocean plastic. In an image showing a  plastic spray bottle of Windex cleaner in front of a pile of colorful plastic bottles. The pile of plastic bottles is submerged in water, suggesting it is ocean plastic.
justification:
According to a Federal Trade Commission (FTC) complaint filed against Reckitt, the maker of Windex, the company falsely advertised that its Windex bottles were made from 100% recycled ocean plastic when, in reality, they contained only 13% recycled plastic, and that recycled plastic did not come from the ocean. This directly contradicts the claim made in the advertisement.
</OUTPUT>

claim: an Instagram post by Brewdog, published on 31 July 2023, featured an image of a poster, containing a childlike drawing of Earth covered in flames. Text accompanying the drawing stated “drink it for me” in the style of a child’s handwriting. Text on the other half of the poster stated “BEER FOR YOUR GRANDCHILDREN”, alongside an image of Brewdog Punk IPA Lager, and a badge with the text “Positive Planet CERTIFIED CARBON NEGATIVE COMPANY”. The caption stated “Beer for your Grandchildren. From the World’s First Carbon Negative brewery. Find out how we’re working to ensure we have a planet to enjoy beer on via the link in our bio”.
justification:
Brewdog claims to be a “Carbon Negative Company” and implies their beer ensures a planet to enjoy beer on for future generations. However, in December 2023, the UK’s Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) ruled that Brewdog’s carbon negativity claims were misleading and could not be substantiated. The ASA found that Brewdog had offset more carbon than it produced in 2021 by purchasing credits from a project that was not independently verified, and that Brewdog had not provided sufficient evidence to demonstrate that it would remain carbon negative in the future. The ASA banned the ad, stating it “misleadingly implied that Brewdog was taking significant action to address its environmental impact.” The claim directly contradicts the ASA ruling and evidence of unsubstantiated carbon negativity.
</OUTPUT>

claim: The poster featured an aerial image of waves crashing on a shore with text that stated "Climate change doesn’t do borders. Neither do rising sea levels. That’s why HSBC is aiming to provide up to $1 trillion in financing and investment globally to help our clients transition to net zero”.
justification:
The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) ruled that HSBC’s advertising was misleading. The ASA found that HSBC was funding investments in fossil fuels while simultaneously promoting its commitment to achieving net zero. Specifically, the ASA noted that HSBC continued to finance companies that actively expanded their fossil fuel production, contradicting the claim that they were helping clients transition to net zero. This constitutes a direct contradiction between the claim and HSBC’s actions, as evidenced by the ASA ruling.
</OUTPUT>

claim: The poster featured an image of tree growth rings with text that stated "Climate changes doesn’t do borders. So in the UK, we’re helping to plant 2 million trees which will lock in 1.25 million tonnes of carbon over their lifetime".

claim: A website for Hyundai, included text which stated “All-New NEXO” and “Introducing the next generation of fuel cell vehicles: All-New NEXO. A car so beautifully clean, it purifies the air as it goes”.
justification:
The UK Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) ruled that Hyundai’s claim that the NEXO “purifies the air as it goes” was misleading and could not be substantiated. While the vehicle emits only water, the ASA found that the overall lifecycle impact of producing and disposing of a fuel cell vehicle, including the production of hydrogen, results in carbon emissions. Therefore, the claim of purifying the air was deemed inaccurate and misleading, as it did not account for the full environmental impact.
</OUTPUT>

claim: “ 100% recycled bottle" accompanied by an asterisk after the claim, leading to text in smaller print on the back of the bottle, specifying “This bottle is made from 100% recycled plastic, so the colour of the bottle may vary. justification:
The claim states "100% recycled bottle" but the asterisk and accompanying fine print reveal that only the bottle itself is made from 100% recycled plastic. The caps and label are not made from recycled plastic. This presents a partial truth as a whole, implying the entire packaging is recycled when it is not.

claim: Made from 100% recycled PET bottles” accompanied by an asterisk after the claim, leading to “*does not refer to the label and cap”.

This is a partial truth presented as a whole, constituting greenwashing.
</OUTPUT>
